bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 25, 1929

div1.p: Agramonte writes to Kean about his family, the pension delay, and his health.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 25, 1929
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K. ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA
August 25th, 1929
Pen file
Assoc'n Military Surgeons, U.S.
AUG 31 1929
Secretary-Editor's Office
Col. J. R. Kean, U.S.A. (Ret.)
The Military Surgeon,
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
This is to answer your kind note of the 22d.
Maj. Gen. Ignacio Agramonte, Killed in action at Jimaguayú, on
May 11, 1873 was my uncle. My father was Eduardo Agramonte, Brig-Gen.
also killed in action on March 8th, 1872 at San José del Chorri-
llo, Camagüey Province, (then Puerto Principe.)

I wondered what was the hitch that kept me from hearing a
word regarding the medal and pension voted by Congress but, to
tell the truth, I was not impatient about it. I only hope that
I may live long enough to enjoy some of it.

I may say that there is nothing the matter with me as yet,
Heart, lungs, liver, digestive apparatus, etc. seems to be in
great shape, the blood pressure is 13o- 90: so there does not
appear to be immediate danger. We remained in Havana this summer,
because my daughter, (the only one,) had to prepare a thesis to
finish her University studies; she is now a Doctor of Pedagogy,
something like the degree of Master of Arts in the Saxon universi-
ties. We have spent most of the time on the water, sailing up and
down the coast in a small sailing vessel that I had built last
Spring; I assure you we have had a lot of fun out of it.
I hope you are keeping fit. With best wishes, I remain,
